title: Poor Psychological Detachment from Work During Leisure Time: Antecedents, Implications for Employee Well-Being, and Intervention Effects
abstractText: It is becoming increasingly apparent that the ability to psychologically detach (or “switch off”) from work during leisure time is an important factor in employee recovery, well-being, and performance. The current research programme has three broad aims: 1) to investigate the individual and work-related antecedents of poor psychological detachment from work during evenings and weekends amongst UK healthcare and central government employees; 2) to examine the impact of poor psychological detachment from work on employees’ psychological health and work performance; and 3) to evaluate a worksite training programme designed to enhance healthy detachment, well-being, and recovery. The first study will use questionnaires and a daily survey method to assess individual and work-related predictors of psychological detachment from work across three or four evenings in the same working week. Study two will employ a weekend respite design to assess the role of weekend experiences in helping employees psychologically detach and recover from the demands of work. The final study will use a randomised controlled group design to evaluate a mindfulness-based psychological skills training programme focused on enhancing recovery and general well-being.
